newsitem.title: UK: Daiwa cuts Dutch equities as options squeeze looms.
newsitem.headline: Daiwa cuts Dutch equities as options squeeze looms.

text.p: Daiwa Europe strategist Roger Monson said he has downgraded Dutch equities to neutral on a six month view after a strong rally over the past year and in the face of a possible options squeeze later this week.
A strategy note from Daiwa said a wide range of options will expire on Friday, "many of them now in the money and set to force the writers to purchase shares and share baskets".
"The AEX has been moving to record highs almost daily this month and the buying implied will only add to this trend," Monson said. "We may see the AEX move above 680 on Friday."
He said during 1996 Dutch shares returned a healthy 24.2 percent in dollar terms, placing the market eighth among 17 European bourses.

"Now with the average price earnings ratio for 1997 at 15.9x, Amsterdam has lost its traditional position at a discount to other major markets and is also selling at 20 percent above its own historical average with a below-average dividend."

"Despite the high quality of Dutch companies and the market's earnings predictability, we cannot argue for more than a return matching the European average for the next six months. We have therefore downgraded the market to a neutral weighting."
